channel.title: Need help with doors please {718/752}
channel.description: Hello, I found a new area that I would like to use but I am not too familiar with making doors work. Any help will be greatly appreciated, thanks.

item.title: Need help with doors please {718/752}
item.dc:creator: @xXSh0ckXx xXSh0ckXx
item.description:
@xXSh0ckXx wrote:

[quote=“sk8rdude461, post:5, topic:553677”][quote author=xXSh0ckXx link=topic=672597.msg4498053#msg4498053 date=1446213404]
So, you’re saying that there two id’s for one door, each either closed or opened?
[/quote]Correct. One for the open state, one for the closed.

[quote author=xXSh0ckXx link=topic=672597.msg4498053#msg4498053 date=1446213404]
For instance, we’re having the door id 50, which means it’s already open
so closed would be 49? Meh.
[/quote]I’m not sure, it depends on the object. But typically the one with the “Open” option will be the lower number.

Oh well, haha, I managed to use the same tile and same object but a different rotation. Pretty much independent of id’s (except the door id’s itself) and perfect for a system supporting all doors.

It’s possible to use a single object, yes. Doing it that way will typically leave your opened door facing backwards, or your closed one (Depending which id you used).
But if you want it done to match runescape (aka “properly”), you have to use the second id as well (Because when open it gives a “close” option).
Here’s a gif of me opening/closing double doors. If you look, when open, there’s a space between the door and the empty window object.[/quote]
Ah. You’re right, I forgot the options part.

Read full topic

item.title: Need help with doors please {718/752}
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

[quote=“xXSh0ckXx, post:4, topic:553677”]So, you’re saying that there two id’s for one door, each either closed or opened?[/quote]Correct. One for the open state, one for the closed.

[quote=“xXSh0ckXx, post:4, topic:553677”]For instance, we’re having the door id 50, which means it’s already open
so closed would be 49? Meh.[/quote]I’m not sure, it depends on the object. But typically the one with the “Open” option will be the lower number.

xXSh0ckXx:

Oh well, haha, I managed to use the same tile and same object but a different rotation. Pretty much independent of id’s (except the door id’s itself) and perfect for a system supporting all doors.

It’s possible to use a single object, yes. Doing it that way will typically leave your opened door facing backwards, or your closed one (Depending which id you used).
But if you want it done to match runescape (aka “properly”), you have to use the second id as well (Because when open it gives a “close” option).
Here’s a gif of me opening/closing double doors. If you look, when open, there’s a space between the door and the empty window object.

Read full topic

item.title: Need help with doors please {718/752}
item.dc:creator: @xXSh0ckXx xXSh0ckXx
item.description:
@xXSh0ckXx wrote:

[quote=“sk8rdude461, post:3, topic:553677”][quote author=xXSh0ckXx link=topic=672597.msg4497931#msg4497931 date=1446035014]

Hello, I found a new area that I would like to use but I am not too familiar with making doors work. Any help will be greatly appreciated, thanks.

Look into the class where object interaction is being handled, and then either replace the existing object with a new one which has a different rotation, or just modify the object so that it would change its rotation. That’d be one way.
[/quote]
Believe it or not, runescape doesn’t keep the open door on the same tile as the closed door, or vice versa. I figured this out when I was working on doors for my POH.

The proper way to make doors work is like so:
Get the door’s object id, and position (x, y, z).
If the door is already open, the id it requires should be is 1 less than the door’s ID. If the door is closed, it should need the ID that’s 1 above the door’s ID. However, in some special cases this isn’t true.
Once a player clicks a door, you move it 1 tile off (This depends on what way the door opens/closes), and then replace it with the new ID from above.[/quote]

So, you’re saying that there two id’s for one door, each either closed or opened?

For instance, we’re having the door id 50, which means it’s already open
so closed would be 49? Meh.

Oh well, haha, I managed to use the same tile and same object but a different rotation. Pretty much independent of id’s (except the door id’s itself) and perfect for a system supporting all doors.

Read full topic

item.title: Need help with doors please {718/752}
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

[quote=“xXSh0ckXx, post:2, topic:553677”][quote author=loliateyourcat link=topic=672597.msg4497923#msg4497923 date=1446016997]
Hello, I found a new area that I would like to use but I am not too familiar with making doors work. Any help will be greatly appreciated, thanks.
[/quote]
Look into the class where object interaction is being handled, and then either replace the existing object with a new one which has a different rotation, or just modify the object so that it would change its rotation. That’d be one way.[/quote]
Believe it or not, runescape doesn’t keep the open door on the same tile as the closed door, or vice versa. I figured this out when I was working on doors for my POH.

The proper way to make doors work is like so:
Get the door’s object id, and position (x, y, z).
If the door is already open, the id it requires should be is 1 less than the door’s ID. If the door is closed, it should need the ID that’s 1 above the door’s ID. However, in some special cases this isn’t true.
Once a player clicks a door, you move it 1 tile off (This depends on what way the door opens/closes), and then replace it with the new ID from above.

Read full topic

item.title: Need help with doors please {718/752}
item.dc:creator: @xXSh0ckXx xXSh0ckXx
item.description:
@xXSh0ckXx wrote:

loliateyourcat:

Hello, I found a new area that I would like to use but I am not too familiar with making doors work. Any help will be greatly appreciated, thanks.

Look into the class where object interaction is being handled, and then either replace the existing object with a new one which has a different rotation, or just modify the object so that it would change its rotation. That’d be one way.
